F7277B39F058452DACBD8C77E7B2D899.description: Prepare for an interview and/or an audition.

16A3A820D36F42EC9598E0C03ED8BDC7.description: Complete a survey to identify careers that would suit one’s strengths, beliefs and interests.

B2A6E09081184392A4C9FBBA6791ED5F.description: Investigate and describe various careers related to entrepreneurship or freelancing in dance (e.g., dance studio owner, photographer, videographer, marketer, event planner, critic, agent, dance wear designer/creator/provider).

8B81CB8E3D35456CA89184BDD16C9D0C.description: Investigate and describe various careers related to health and wellness in dance (e.g., teacher/instructor for Pilates/yoga, fitness trainer, massage therapist, physiotherapist).

6AA87C7CE9234DFEA08D5B1B187ACC6F.description: Investigate and describe various careers associated with dance creation and/or production (e.g., choreographer/dance maker, performer, costume designer, lighting designer, stage manager, director, teacher, music editor, production crew).

ECE6CBF7A6584A0894B7ACE6D6223A81.description: Analyze and explore a dance-related career path related to own interests.

BE0175002B394CCDBCB4A30E2B56B0C3.description: Reflect on the development of one’s personal voice in dance.

9490812128914CA8AA41B8841A3343A7.description: Explore other artists’ work related to global issues and explore similar issues through own evolving personal voice.

B29A727790D84F85848BBE98920E804E.description: Explore and respond to dance practices within a range of cultural and environmental contexts (e.g., legends, myths, ceremonies, influence of nature).

7553C4A5027A447A9CE1635261CD2A8B.description: Investigate how various dance types and styles emerge and evolve in response to historical and/or current cultural shifts.

28EE48E644DE43B78A7EF0E0CF481EDA.description: Acknowledge and describe how a variety of worldviews influence personal voice through dance.

7182446954BC463199E7A925C57DEE3A.description: Examine international choreographers who are pioneers in new movements or genres of dance.

9D7FB56149244B7B8ADEBD06328C0C34.description: Survey and respond to a range of world dance types and styles, including dances of Indigenous peoples.

093B95EDAFD6493C9B8D0B51AFB3CBE8.description: Develop personal voice in dance within the context of contemporary world issues and/or events.

E60F6EC8D83C48ED8114C42265ED2E68.description: Investigate the connection between specific cultural spiritualties and dance.

7035F219A0CC4A2FA0578CD3B4CD7AFF.description: Create a global timeline (e.g., photograph, tableau, video and drawing) of historical milestones in dance.

1F8FDE10660E46E5A22C9C8D55E44363.description: Explore other artists’ work related to a historical event or issue and examine a similar event or issue through own self-expression.

82F8C6AE713F4D93AED3C59E71558759.description: Explore a variety of historical world events in relation to self-expression through dance.

E91998CF36224F479216DE039F3E2D7E.description: Develop a dance in response to a global historical issue.

3894E86B3E43434E8C8BD5F60C2500C5.description: Examine a retrospective of a choreographers’ (e.g., Alvin Ailey, Merce Cunningham, Isadora Duncan) and/or companies’ work, (e.g., Toronto Dance Theatre, National Ballet School, Netherlands Dance Theatre, Martha Graham Company).

8E6B9EBF53284C7B956239095939B92A.description: Discuss how specific dances evolved from historical events.

9367E28090E749E28E8F778040638EC0.description: Examine how world views changed throughout time and the effects that has had on dance.

958716030C574006A191F0792616039D.description: Develop personal voice in dance expressed within a global historical context.

3A76648CE47E4A3196A1A78E6B15C069.description: Conduct research (e.g., digital, live, interview) on a contemporary International Indigenous dance maker and report on such things as: philosophy or focus, subject or themes presented, discipline specific or interdisciplinary work, and the potential influence of traditional practices (e.g., ask inquiry questions such as Do traditional practices and/or Elders influence the work you create? Does your culture influence the subject matter or themes of your work?).

DF37C55F0EE941DCABD7E3E848339B46.description: Examine and describe the different complexities related to the roles of men and women in traditional dance around the world.

EF7EA389AB4F41F0A7FC2311FF12F30C.description: Compare various Indigenous dance protocols and their purposes.

E323CA1229094CD483EA0702C3553843.description: Recognize the role of dance in developing and expressing identity in Indigenous communities around the world.

9722587208474C099A680D912730FA21.description: Examine the role of dance in resisting colonial assimilation policies in various parts of the world (e.g., treaty education outcome SI11 -analyze how the unfulfilled aspects of treaties, with international indigenous people, have resulted in inequities)

96D1FA885E1648F89BC190B915B990C9.description: Analyze the role of dance in preserving and celebrating cultural identity.

14A8F66F0D304E3CA6C701D26D7E9398.description: Discuss the history and role of dance in Indigenous cultures around the world.

E03E83E6E05B434AAFFB4E6FD35E64D1.description: Examine the role of dance in expressing identity, drawing where possible and appropriate on the experience of students and expertise of community members.

F857D83DD9894A89A3679FDE6C457CED.description: Engage, digitally or in-person, with Indigenous Elders, Knowledge Keepers, community leaders and/or dancers to learn about the role and history of dance in Indigenous communities.

C0EB659B196E4A46A4B1EAD42DC31121.description: Examine the role of dance in expressing Indigenous cultural and individual identity, past and present.

0C751D5E59D74339A1B244727E8D4AED.description: Cultural/Historical (CH) Goal: Students will investigate the content and aesthetics of the arts within cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts, and understand the connection between the arts and the human experience.

F946BA3DF38F4E02B19AD147ED454FF7.description: Identify the ethical responsibilities, such as obtaining permissions and rights, involved in interpreting and presenting interdisciplinary work (e.g., dancing to a poem, learning First Nations dances).

2996C8042EFC40B9A1B688CCC1F9E2EA.description: Examine contemporary dance practices and other arts disciplines that include hybrid forms and/or cultural fusions (e.g., Bollywood, Travis Wall’s Strange Fruit in response to slavery and Black Lives Matter).

EB90D225858E42278F7BB0A363841E17.description: Research and discuss examples of appropriation in dance (e.g., case studies).

F69BDD82B57D46D7B11F0CD7C37CB75A.description: Generate questions related to appropriation (e.g., What is cultural appropriation? How does this knowledge affect the way students are working with dance?).

DA2D61FE45DC444AA6A260CA985CCF6D.description: Examine the ethics related to accessing and interpreting material in dance and the arts.

EEE08D34C6AE4B95BC755967F1DEDC16.description: Take part in, analyze and respond to dances that reflect social and political conditions on a global level.

CB6E070425D14BADA007B299A64323D2.description: View, reflect upon and respond to dances that reflect social and political conditions on a global level.

26FAB44BDFBC48E2A3A11B87668B7D89.description: Transfer understanding of international dance makers’ work into own dance compositions.

C44BB497279B4FF9B3D489460EA65266.description: Research ways that international dancers and dance makers raise awareness of global issues through dance.

5AA7820DC2A94548B589611F68CE527D.description: Describe how dances from around the world are influenced by social and political conditions.

4A5860D1EB914B74B8B81F3C18C1C2DA.description: Examine the origins and evolution of dances from around the world to identify how social and political conditions influenced the work (e.g., Pena Bausch, African gumboot dance as a response to Apartheid).

8C464CBA38F843EBA6FAC172427C7CBE.description: Analyze how dance reflects social and political conditions on a global level.

9F0947FABFC84C9991FD5C405739A814.description: Respond to dance compositions on an emotional, associative and formal intellectual level using selected approach and/or processes such as those described in Responding to Arts Expressions (see online curriculum resources).

FD29BC983CA44207AA891163298B9386.description: Assess dance compositions using collaboratively-developed criteria including use of dance elements and choreographic form (e.g., canon, ABA, rondo) and devices (e.g., repetition, contrast, tension).

3E2EB004543E45BC82F833EDE2B25FAC.description: Examine and discuss how dance compositions convey ideas, vision and/or messages.

F307DC32AAEE4B309CFBDD1CB376DD36.description: Respond to own, peers’ and others’ dance compositions, through various means (e.g., written, blog, discussion, interdisciplinary creation).

2F8EA40F98F343F899BF7D90E9F3DDBF.description: Identify and articulate strengths and areas for improvement in own and peers’ work.

05A0B2E2E53A4233ADF76AEAB8E1A52F.description: Identify and articulate goals and intentions for dance, based on collaboratively-developed and relevant criteria (e.g., time: duration, rhythm, tempo).

FD1AB4E4EDDF4CEE8169AA0F2E65DF1E.description: Develop criteria and use related terminology to analyze dance compositions.

20228C6E138946BABA964F8EAEEEA256.description: Respond critically and constructively to dance compositions using collaboratively-developed criteria.

F7A6D1730B9642A6AAB6EC6B3E8006D3.description: Take personal risks in developing and sharing dance work.

E6FD5D57D4324F6DB2820C1B8A2659B4.description: Investigate how dance can address larger questions of human existence and perspectives (e.g., world peace, sustainability).

FE873A94346F4717B248BD969B6ADFF1.description: Reflect on how dance has created a sense of community in the classroom, school and global community.

AE0C5554B5C84803A5210BFB4FA51847.description: Discuss and compare international dance makers who demonstrate social and critical engagement in society (e.g., working with newcomers on dance work).

6B36B368188B42F09AA440CE638A0203.description: Research choreographers and dance makers whose work promotes compassion and empathy (e.g., research choreographers whose work responds to newcomers’ experience).

0FAB945C850F4A89B389650A98537693.description: Research a range of training methods and somatic practices (e.g., yoga, Pilates, F.M. Alexander Technique, Laban analysis) that promote physical health and well-being.

BB7930D13B06483EA164D30919CA33C7.description: Research and justify choice of International dancers and/or dance makers and other inspirational role models

C7DD948D16E0486FA888A9B1EAF8C7B3.description: Adapt personal expression in response to information from others (e.g., peers, audience, choreographer).

B139548662C64AB2A03A2C930EAA48F7.description: Reflect on personal beliefs while addressing common misconceptions about dance.

1279FE741DFA4BFEB63555D73801C2D7.description: Explore mindful and/or contemplative exercises (e.g., written reflection, video, blog) as a daily dance practice.

8F84A74BC01A4DB9A61CF0D15F88D592.description: Create a dance portfolio (e.g., digital, written) as a reflective inventory of growth and progress

B44F7C9548C54E4393517969225FDD04.description: Examine how dance deepens one’s insight into self and expands relationship with others and the world.

661F1D4D22EC42BAA7BFEFCF80937F73.description: Critical/Responsive (CR) Goal: Students will respond to artistic expressions of Saskatchewan, Canadian, and International artists using critical thinking, research, creativity, and collaborative inquiry.

496ADD97760147949FB0BF1C4A2F2476.description: Apply peer and teacher feedback during rehearsal process to improve performance.

15D94F239BDE46A79174412B37B5972A.description: Co-construct, with guidance, criteria for evaluating performance.

09351CCF1D064C928F3CACDAF80E78D6.description: Demonstrate one’s optimal level of ability when dancing.

32BA3AA2554947B5A5688B78481BADBC.description: Rehearse and refine composition to convey the dance maker’s vision.

C82EAC2D63034D5F8DD7FA3B5F033470.description: Collaborate, problem solve and communicate clearly during rehearsal and dance performance (e.g., making adjustments in the moment, dealing with unforeseen technical difficulties).

52AE0C17FC784F61916772535A248561.description: Perform dances inspired by the work of recognized international dance makers.

5EF9D1B0D56E473B97DE65F218190281.description: Perform movement or dance composition to convey global perspectives.

D8875EB610984BFF9E1903D07DC79AAD.description: Perform solo, duo or group dances to reflect global perspectives.

B18D0E14C9BA4B9DAD18E6CD7DA368FF.description: Keep a record of dance-making ideas and choreography using student-invented notation.

D30BD4136C81482AA5007BEF0C2A0515.description: Collaborate with peers and teacher during dance-making process.

491CFB61CCFC4F35A310E13D98AD2A4F.description: Practise collaboration, problem solving and clear communication during the dance-making process.

6B1A7EE2D2284C44862E06E792A1C77A.description: Adapt choreography for a range of abilities.

40B6426974534EEFADA970C254E8EB68.description: Create dance with a focus on social justice (e.g., immigration, education, gender equality) and cultural diversity in a global context.

41CF24CA7FD64A0E8B8358E90E3EA7A2.description: Incorporate an international dance maker’s ideas and movement style into a dance composition.

0E95B05DDA574B4B9FE89A4E1C2CC912.description: Research international choreographers’ methods and practices.

B8D8CC9CED464E45AEE746D5258B8C17.description: Demonstrate effective use of dance elements and choreographic form in dance-making process.

02E66E312EAE4A2A82562549AD08142E.description: Use another art form (e.g., drama, visual art, music) or discipline (e.g., science, social studies, physical education) as inspiration for dance making.

3915971969C14392B3D7B3ABC729BC1B.description: Create movement or dance composition inspired by world dance and/or global perspectives

CEDB2460C7AD473593DC2BD264974FF3.description: Create solo, duo or group dances to reflect global perspectives.

84C888E0BC3F43D9AB1810C656F79817.description: Practise the protocols and expectations associated with world dance.

90392320E0164EC587CBDEAA44A773D2.description: Refine technique associated with different world dance types and styles.

91E43CE949664274A537211BD66FD262.description: Apply, with guidance, body alignment specific to dance type and style (e.g., Afro beat, Irish dance).

61987AC91CF446A793C31B7C62A248F3.description: Apply elements of dance (e.g., body, actions, space, time, energy) appropriate for various dance types and styles.

8C88AD28A4D14772BD2045603256173B.description: Demonstrate knowledge of dance technique, terminology and protocols associated with various world dances.

44545B4C5E344B568F231AB63490CD6A.description: Execute warm-up and cool-down activities appropriate to the type and style of dance.

499E8BA4A03B479C96E86CB32ADEDA65.description: Apply, with guidance, technique and strategies for safe execution of dance movements (e.g., lifts).

3902F600F25943B8BC2F3D76EEED2C7D.description: Experiment with various dance types and styles and differentiate the techniques and associated terminology (e.g., ballroom as a type of dance including waltz, foxtrot or tango styles; ballet as a type of dance including classical or contemporary styles; powwow as a type of dance including grass or fancy styles; modern as a type of dance including Graham or contact improvisation styles; hip hop as a type of dance including B-boying, funk, or up rock styles).

E4D86A2B8C954B03A80ED8A6AE74079C.description: Experiment with dance technique within a range of global contexts.

AA7A6C50675F49EBAA4C3182E3BC679D.description: Creative/Productive (CP) Goal: Students will inquire, create, and communicate through dance, drama, music and visual art.
